misconceptions.name: Reads point coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program is written to read four doubles representing two 2D points (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100. There is no variable that stores a grade and no prompt like 'Enter grade:'.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read coordinates for two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) and process them, rather than to read a single numeric grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read exactly one numeric grade value (e.g., an int or double) from the user, typically with a prompt such as 'Enter grade: ', and store it in a single variable like 'grade'.
symptoms: Prompts 'Enter x1 and y1' and 'Enter x2 and y2' instead of 'Enter grade'
Declares variables x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade variable
Uses multiple calls to nextDouble() to read four numbers instead of one
misconceptions.root_cause: The student reused or submitted code for a different problem (distance between points) instead of implementing the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate input section with a single variable, such as 'int grade', and read exactly one value from the user (e.g., 'System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();').
related_concepts: Designing program input based on requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input-related code is for reading four doubles as coordinates with prompts mentioning x1, y1, x2, y2; there is no mention of grades anywhere.

evidence.note: This code reads four doubles as coordinates with prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2; it does not read a single numeric grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges (A and B)
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a grade is in the ranges 90-100 or 80-89 and does not contain any if/else conditions related to grades at all. Instead, it computes a geometric distance.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to compute the distance between two points and therefore does not include any conditional logic for grade ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use conditional statements (if/else-if/else) to test whether the numeric grade is in the A range (90-100) or B range (80-89) and branch accordingly.
symptoms: No if or else-if statements referencing a grade variable
All arithmetic focuses on dx, dy, and distance instead of grade thresholds like 90 or 80
misconceptions.root_cause: Student implemented an entirely different algorithm that does not involve grading logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if-else chain based on the 'grade' variable, e.g., 'if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... }', to correctly handle A and B ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional statements related to grades or ranges; the only computation is distance using dx and dy.

evidence.note: This section performs distance calculations instead of any conditional checks for A or B grade ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges (C and D)
misconceptions.description: There is no code to check whether a grade is between 70-79 or 60-69 or to handle those specific ranges. The program has no grade-related Boolean expressions at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student is not attempting any grade range checks and is instead focused on a geometry problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should have conditional branches that test whether the grade falls into the C (70-79) or D (60-69) ranges and set the output letter accordingly.
symptoms: No comparisons against thresholds 70 or 60
No structure like 'else if (grade >= 70)' or 'else if (grade >= 60)'
misconceptions.root_cause: Entire grading logic is absent due to implementing the wrong problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the if-else chain to include conditions for 'grade >= 70' (C) and 'grade >= 60' (D) after handling A and B.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no grade variable and no range comparisons for C or D; only distance computation is present.

evidence.note: The entire main method solves a distance problem and never performs any range checking that would correspond to C or D grades.

misconceptions.name: No default or else case to handle failing grades
misconceptions.description: There is no conditional structure at all, so there cannot be a final else or default case to assign 'F' to any grade below 60.
misconceptions.student_belief: Because the student is not implementing grade logic, they do not account for a default case for grades below any threshold.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After checking for A, B, C, and D ranges with if/else-if, the program should use an else branch to handle all remaining grades (below 60) and output 'F'.
symptoms: No if/else/else-if blocks in the program
No handling for invalid or low values, because grades are never considered at all
misconceptions.root_cause: The grading design pattern (with a final else for F) is not applied because the student solved an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a final 'else' in the grade-checking chain that prints 'F' for any grade not already matched by previous conditions.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any conditional logic means there is no way for the program to provide a default F case.

evidence.note: Program computes and prints distance and then exits; there is no conditional or default 'else' handling, so F is never considered.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs numeric distance instead of letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program's only output is a message about the distance between two points, and it never prints any letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on an input grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should display the distance of two points as the final result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should output 'Letter grade: X', where X is a single character (A-F) determined from the input numeric grade.
symptoms: Output string mentions 'The distance of the two points' instead of 'Letter grade:'
No string literals 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D', or 'F' appear in the code
misconceptions.root_cause: Student implemented output for an unrelated distance calculation problem instead of mapping grade ranges to letters.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance print statement with one that prints the letter grade, e.g., 'System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter);', where 'letter' is computed from the grade.
related_concepts: Designing program output to match a specification
Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only println call prints a distance message; there is no mention of letter grades anywhere.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: This is the sole user-visible output, and it reports a distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Failure to Address Prompt (Submitted solution for another problem)
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a different programming task (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem (Q3). The entire implementation, including variable declarations, input prompts, calculation logic, and output, is incorrect for the assigned problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either believes the submitted code is the correct solution for the Grade Calculator problem, or they mistakenly submitted a solution for a different problem (e.g., Q1 or Q2) in place of Q3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade and implementing conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade based on predefined ranges.
symptoms: Variables are declared for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Prompts ask for coordinate pairs
Calculations involve the distance formula (Math.sqrt)
Output displays a distance, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Missubmission or failure to read and understand the specific requirements for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement (Q3) and write code that specifically implements the grade calculation logic using input reading and conditional statements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence, as the student's code fully solves a distance calculation problem, which is completely distinct from the required grade calculation problem.

evidence.note: The class name, variable declarations (x1, y1, x2, y2), and input prompt ('Enter x1 and y1: ') clearly indicate a geometry problem, not a grade calculator.
The core calculation solves for distance, and the output prints the distance, showing no attempt at implementing the required letter grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Mismatch - Submitted Wrong Program
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code for a different problem (distance calculator) instead of the required grade calculator problem. This indicates either a file mix-up or fundamental task confusion.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to calculate the Euclidean distance between two points given their coordinates.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade value
Prompts ask for coordinates, not a grade
Output displays distance calculation instead of letter grade
Class name is DistanceBetweenPoints, not related to grades
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely file submission error or copy-paste from a different assignment. The student may have submitted the wrong solution file or confused this task with another programming exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify that you are submitting the correct file for the Grade Calculator assignment. Delete this code and write a new program that: (1) reads a single integer grade, (2) uses if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The code solves a completely different problem with a different class name, different input variables, different prompts, and different output. This is not a subtle logic error but a fundamental program mismatch.

evidence.note: Class name and variable declarations are for distance calculation, not grade classification
Prompts and reads for x1/y1 coordinates instead of a single grade value

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);

    System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Output displays Euclidean distance, not a letter grade. No grade classification logic exists.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance-between-points program instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) instead of a grade calculator that reads a single numeric grade (0–100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A–F). None of the required input, conditional ranges, or letter-grade outputs are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to solve a 'Distance Between Points' problem, reading four doubles and computing their Euclidean distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read one numeric grade (0–100) from the user, then use conditionals to map that numeric grade into a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges, and finally print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
No variable or prompt related to a grade or letter grade.
No conditional logic to check grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.).
Final output reports a numeric distance, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely the student submitted code for a different exercise (Distance Between Points) instead of the grade calculator problem, indicating confusion about the assignment requirements or a mix-up in files.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start from the required behavior: read one numeric grade, use if/else-if conditions to check which range it falls into, and print the corresponding letter. Make sure the program name, prompts, and output all match the grade-calculator specification rather than another problem.
related_concepts: Selecting appropriate inputs and outputs for a task
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, prompts, variables, and calculations are all clearly tailored to a distance-between-points problem and do not reference grades or letter grades at all.

evidence.note: Entire program is built around reading coordinates and computing Euclidean distance; there is no reading of a single grade value, no grade-range conditionals, and no letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Solved the Wrong Problem (Distance Calculator)

symptoms: Code reads four floating-point inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2)
Calculates Euclidean distance

misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or submitting an entirely incorrect file/solution.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. The task requires reading *one* number (the grade) and using `if/else if/else` logic to categorize it, not calculating distance.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code logic is for a completely different task (distance calculation).

evidence.note: The class name suggests the code is for a different problem.
Variables are defined for coordinate geometry, not a single grade input.

evidence.snippet:

misconceptions.name: Excessive Input Validation Loops
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple `while (!input.hasNextDouble()) { input.next(); }` loops directly preceding every call to `input.nextDouble()`. While this structure attempts robust input handling, using separate `while` loops for sequential reads is overly verbose and duplicates logic, confusing the standard practice of reading multiple inputs efficiently or validating a single input in one streamlined block.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that every single `input.nextDouble()` call must be preceded by an individual loop to buffer or skip non-double inputs, even when subsequent inputs are being read in succession.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Input validation is typically handled by structuring input requests within a single loop that continues until valid data is attained. While robust, the repetitive structure here is inefficient and indicates a lack of understanding of how to sequence input reads when multiple values are expected and validated.
symptoms: The same 4 lines of validation logic are repeated four times.
misconceptions.root_cause: Over-generalization of a specific validation idiom (robustly handling bad input) and applying it to sequential input reading, leading to excessively repetitive code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: If reading multiple values at once is desired, consider validating the entire line of input or simplifying the input sequence. For the intended grade calculator problem, only one input is needed, simplifying the required input loop structure significantly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The pattern is repeated exactly four times for four inputs, demonstrating a specific, albeit inefficient, procedural choice for input handling.

evidence.note: Repetitive validation loops for sequential inputs.
The same repetitive structure is used again for the next two inputs.

No grade category checking (90-100, 80-89, etc.)
misconceptions.root_cause: Either accidental file submission error or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify you are working on the correct problem. Start fresh with: (1) Read a single grade input, (2) Use if/else with Boolean conditions for ranges, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: 100% confidence — the submitted code objectively solves a completely different problem with no overlap to grade calculation requirements.

evidence.note: Class name and variable declarations indicate distance calculation, not grade logic

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
